newsitem.title: UK: Grand Prix business may not race to flotation.
newsitem.headline: Grand Prix business may not race to flotation.

text.p: The prospect of investors buying shares in Formula One motor racing receded on Sunday when the sport's top businessman told a British newspaper he had no wish to proceed at full throttle towards a flotation.

Bernie Ecclestone told the Sunday Times he would in any event want to retain a majority holding in the sport he at present controls. "My feeling is to wait and see (about offering shares to other investors)," Ecclestone said.

He said Salomon Brothers, the merchant bank he has hired to advise him, had told him his attitude was silly. "They may have wanted to put pressure on me. One thing is for sure -- it certainly won't force me to do it," Ecclestone said.

The entrepreneur, president of the Formula One Constructors' Association and owner of the sport's promotion arm, has transformed Grand Prix racing into a spectacular attracting a 450 million global television audience for every event.

Now he stands to make some two billion pounds ($3 billion) through a flotation. But Ecclestone is already a multi-millionaire and one of the richest men in Britain, where he lives in a mansion block in Chelsea, London.
He said he may now delay a flotation until money starts to flow in from deals with pay television channels. These, he said, could "bring in an enormous profit and give Formula One its full worth".
If the flotation goes ahead, it could capitalise on British investors' thirst for high-profile sports businesses.
Newcastle United is currently one of several top soccer clubs planning to join Manchester United and Tottenham Hotspur on the stock market.
